entries.title: Russia’s Small Nuclear Arms Are a Risk For Putin and Ukraine
entries.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has 2,000 small nuclear weapons, but their utility on the battlefield may not be worth the longer-term costs.

entries.title: Elon Musk Tweets About How to End  to End the War in Ukraine
entries.description: President Zelensky swiftly dismisses the entrepreneur’s suggestion on Twitter.

entries.title: Election Deniers in U.S. Push Idea of Voting Fraud in Brazil
entries.description: Some prominent election denialists in the United States are using Brazil to try to whip up concern about the approaching midterms.

entries.title: Brittney Griner’s Appeal Hearing Set for Oct. 25, Russian Court Says
entries.description: The United States has sought the release of the W.N.B.A. star, who pleaded guilty to drug possession and was sentenced to nine years.

entries.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Indonesia Investigates Its Soccer Tragedy
entries.description: Plus Brazil’s elections move to a runoff and Ukraine surges forward in the Donbas.

entries.title: Brazil Braces for ‘White-Knuckle Race’ Between Bolsonaro and Lula
entries.description: President Jair Bolsonaro had once looked doomed in the country’s high-stakes election. But now, in a runoff, the right-wing incumbent has a path to re-election.

entries.title: Russian Disarray on Display as Ukraine’s Forces Advance on Two Fronts
entries.description: Kremlin-installed officials said they had lost ground in the east and south, as Moscow acknowledged that the borders of the territory it has illegally annexed were in flux.

entries.title: Deadly Soccer Clash in Indonesia Puts Police Tactics, and Impunity, in Spotlight
entries.description: Experts say officers are almost never held accountable for their actions. And in a huge police budget, millions are spent on tear gas, batons and other devices deployed during protests.

entries.title: A 95-Square-Foot Tokyo Apartment: ‘I Wouldn’t Live Anywhere Else’
entries.description: Meet the young Japanese who have decided to live in a shoe box.

entries.title: Victoria and Albert Museum Reverses Course and Removes Sackler Name
entries.description: The museum’s director had previously said he was not going to erase the name of the Sackler family, which founded Purdue Pharma, the creator of an addictive opioid painkiller.

entries.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Condemns Protests Gripping Country
entries.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, speaking for the first time about the uprising, accused the U.S. and Israel of fomenting unrest and voiced support for the crackdown on protesters.

entries.title: Head of Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Released From Detention
entries.description: The detention by Russia of Ihor Murashov had stoked concerns about the security of Europe’s largest nuclear plant.

entries.title: Éric Dupond-Moretti, French Justice Minister, Faces Trial
entries.description: Éric Dupond-Moretti opened investigations of judges he had clashed with as a lawyer, prompting accusations that he had abused his position to settle scores.

entries.title: Maggie Haberman Talks About Reporting on Donald Trump
entries.description: He often utters falsehoods, but his speaking style is more strategic than it sometimes seems. Listen for the first time to audio clips from interviews with Maggie Haberman.

entries.title: The Kremlin, after trumpeting annexation, admits it doesn’t know where the borders are.
Arema fans gather for a weeklong vigil to pay respects to the dead.
On Russian TV, the Kremlin emphasizes a fight against all of the West, not just Ukraine.
Ukraine’s First Lady, Olena Zelenska, Tells ‘60 Minutes’ of the War’s Impact
entries.description: Olena Zelenska told CBS News that Russian attacks on schools, hospitals and residential areas have been a form of terrorism.

entries.title: Unearthing Everyday Life at an Ancient Site in Greece
entries.description: Excavations in the Peloponnesian village of Iklaina are yielding rich insights into the lives of the Mycenaean civilization’s general population.

entries.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to Be Awarded Today
entries.description: It will be the first Nobel Prize awarded this year, with more announcements being made over the coming week.

entries.title: Indonesian human rights official says tear gas likely played a key role in the disaster.
entries.description: An initial examination shows that police also used violent force against fans. Without gas, the tragedy might have been avoided, the organization said.

entries.title: Truss, in Reversal, Drops Plan to Cut U.K. Tax Rate on High Earners
entries.description: The announcement was a major capitulation by the government after tax cuts it announced roiled financial markets and drew widespread criticism.

entries.title: The investigation will take two weeks, an official says.
Indonesia Appoints Independent Commission to Investigate Deaths
entries.description: Questions remain about why the police used tear gas to disperse fans in the overcrowded stadium. At least 125 people died, many trampled, after Saturday’s game.

entries.title: Your Monday Briefing
entries.description: Nord Stream leakages stop.

entries.title: Bolsonaro Outperforms Polls and Forces Runoff Against Lula in Brazil’s Presidential Election
entries.description: The two political titans will face off again later this month in a race widely seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.

entries.title: Russia’s Annexation Claim Is News to Residents of Lyman, Ukraine
entries.description: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
